items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are rising and forecast to continue rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and forecast rainfall overnight tonight and tomorrow, 13/03/2023. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 12:00 tomorrow, 13/03/2023.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high until 14/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff are closing pointing doors at Torksey tomorrow, around 12:00, 13/03/2023.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 04:30 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Stratford river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall and snow melt overnight.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Sunday, 12/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Dernford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.
 
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 12/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Shipley Gate river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 01:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Pinxton, including the Pinxton Wharf access road, Langley Mill, Ilkeston, Stapleford, and the recreation area at Sandiacre.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until later tomorrow afternoon, 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible this afternoon, 12/03/23, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast  this morning is dry with outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight, which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 12/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise earlier in the week due to the heavy rainfall after a drier period and are expected to continue to respond to the showers particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast in the early evening. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of snow melt and rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 13:30 today, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 4.2 to 4.6 m Monday overnight and Cae Howel - 5.3 to 5.7 m Tuesday overnight. Note: there is additional uncertainty with these peak predictions due to snow melt.
We expect river levels to remain high for several days. Further rainfall is expected on Sunday evening 12/03/23 and Monday morning 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 19:00 on 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin ovenight tonight, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight tonight and into Monday.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days.   
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 08:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.
Further rain is forecast later today, Sunday, and Monday which may cause the river levels to rise again.      
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall slowly at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall and snow melt.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Monday, 12/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels have risen and forecast to continue rising at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of snowmelt and forecast rainfall overnight tonight and tomorrow, 13/03/2023. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 4:00 tomorrow, 13/03/2023.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We expect river levels to remain high until 14/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 04:30 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall and snow melt overnight.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Monday, 12/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case warnings are issued.
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible, especially in the Lower Arncott and Islip areas. 
The forecast this morning is dry with outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight, which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Although river levels have receded, we expect the river levels to rise again with further forecast rainfall later today, 12th March 2023, and the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thame area. 
The forecast this morning is dry with outbreaks of rain this evening and overnight, which may turn heavy at times. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
No property flooding is expected. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the evening and through Sunday 12/03/23.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 11/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault and Earith river gauges as a result of snow melt and heavy rainfall in the upper catchment. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Sunday 12 March and is likely to continue into next week. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, including the causeways at Earith, Sutton Gault and Welney.

UPDATE - this flood alert now also includes the Earith causeway.

This information is correct as of 15:30 on Sunday 12 March. The causeway at Earith has approximately 20cm of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 46cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire County Council Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated again tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 01:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23.   Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until at least Wednesday, 15/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Onibury river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-  Leintwardine 1.5m to 1.9m 13/03 in the afternoon; Onibury peaked at 1.78m 12/03 at 10:00; Corve 2.5m to 2.9m 13/03 in teh afternoon.   
  We expect river levels to remain high for several days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
  
This message will be updated  by 19:00 on 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on Saturday the 11th March 2022 at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. We expect the River Avon to remain high for the next coming days; its possible there will be some flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   

The weather forecast for late Sunday and into Monday suggests further large rainfall totals. We will continue to closely monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated on the 12 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

Please refer to Hazard Manager for additional information. www.metoffice.gov.uk/premium/hazardmanager.

River levels have risen at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from this afternoon, 12/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.   
Further rainfall is forecast for Sunday evening into Monday.
We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
  
This message will be updated by 08:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are high but steady as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting Roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell.
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today, although there is likely to be some rain overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels have fallen but are now holding steady at the Riseley river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain and snow that fell across the River Nene catchment over the last few days has caused the River Nene levels to rise. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are operating the Whittlesey washlands to help manage the situation. This Flood Warning is expected to be in place for a few days, whilst river and tide levels remain high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 19:00 on 12/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook area. This means that Harpers Brook and Willow Brook have risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today, although there is likely to be some rain overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Granta in Essex and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Linton river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Granta from Linton to Babraham.
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. The forecast is for no further rainfall during today, although there is likely to be some rain overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 12 March. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for some rain expected overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am Monday 13 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Rivers Blyth and Walpole and Chediston, Bramfield and Wrentham watercourses
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. There is a small band of rain passing across this evening and another band of rain Sunday evening into Monday. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Sunday 12 March. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in the area. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for some rain expected overnight and the next few days are likely to be unsettled. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am Monday 13 March or as the situation changes.

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Ely Ouse in Cambridgeshire, Suffolk and Norfolk
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Bottisham Lode and Quy Water area. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding could affect Botisham Lode and Quy Water.
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 12/03/23, or as the situation changes.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days, and so river levels could rise again

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels are forecast to rise at the South Wigston river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from 02:00 tomorrow, 13/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including the farmland in Great Glen, Kilby Bridge, South Wigston and Blaby as well as the road at Crow Mills. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam at Eathorpe, Huningham and Offchurch
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have fallen below the flood warning threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued

Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Ise and Alledge Brook area. This means that the River Ise and Alledge Brook have risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Leicestershire, Lincolnshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, Rutland, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall and snow in the River Welland area. This means that The River Welland has risen, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. But further rainfall is forecast for later on Sunday 12th March 2023 and over the next few days. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Rothley Brook and Quorn Brook in Leicestershire
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Glenfield river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from 23:00 today, 12/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including the Morrisons parks at Glenfield and Anstey. Low-lying land and farmlands in the Glenfield, Anstey, Thurcaston, Rothley, Newtown Linford, Cropston, Swithland and Quorn areas. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.
